metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Maheshwari Devi Jute Mills Ltd.

facts.text: Maheshwari Devi Jute Mills Ltd. carries on the business of manufacturing jute goods and is a member of the Jute Mills Association.
Members of the Association entered into an agreement dated January 9, 1932 called the First Working Time Agreement restricting hours of work, to expire on December 11, 1944.
A fresh agreement was executed on June 12, 1944, with preamble stating signatories determined to continue provisions similar to those in the Working Time Agreement due to losses from over-production.

By cl. 4, restrictions on hours of work; loom-hours based on number of looms installed. Cl. 5: working hours per week for registered complement of looms. Cl. 10: max for mills exceeding 220 looms. Cl. 13: registration of loom-hours.
Cl. 6: grouping of mills under same managing agents; transfer of surplus loom-hours to others in group or outside, registered with Association.
Respondent allotted 220 x 72 loom-hours per week.

In account year corresponding to assessment year 1949-50, preparatory section unable to work more than 48 hours/week; sold 220 x 24 loom-hours to Naskarpara Jute Mills for Rs. 53,460/- with Association sanction.
In account year corresponding to assessment year 1950-51, received Rs. 1,85,230/- from Birla Jute Mills and Hanuman Jute Mills for sale of surplus loom-hours.
Income-tax Officer included amounts as revenue receipts liable to tax for 1949-50 and 1950-51; confirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.
Tribunal referred question to Allahabad High Court at instance of respondent: Whether receipts of Rs. 53,460/- and Rs. 1,85,230/- were revenue receipts liable to tax.
High Court answered in negative (judgment March 28, 1961, Income-tax Reference No. 165 of 1954).
Commissioner preferred appeals with certificate under s. 66A(2) of Indian Income-tax Act.
Tribunal held receipts not capital, not casual/non-recurring.
Allahabad High Court in Maheshwari Devi Jute Mills v. CIT (IT Misc. Case No. 177 of 1960, decided Sep 13, 1962) held similar receipts as income.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the receipts of the assessee by the sale of loom-hours amounting to Rs. 53,460/- and Rs. 1,85,230/- in the assessment years 1949-50 and 1950-51 respectively were revenue receipts liable to tax under the Indian Income-tax Act?

petitioner_arguments.text: Receipts for sale of loom-hours are revenue receipts as part of normal business activity to earn profit by exploiting asset, either by using it or letting it out; analogous to rent from idle plant.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Commissioner of Excess Profits, Bombay City v. Shri Lakshmi Silk Mills Ltd.

petitioner_arguments.text: Plea that receipts are casual/non-recurring has no substance; receipt in ordinary course of business is taxable even if casual.

respondent_arguments.text: Receipts for sale of loom-hours are capital receipts, or casual and non-recurring exempt under s. 4(3)(vii).
Loom-hours are a privilege, not an asset.

court_reasoning.text: Receipts not casual/non-recurring exempt under s. 4(3)(vii) as they arise from business; but not from business in loom-hours.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No compensation paid by Association; facility to transfer provided to protect interests.

court_reasoning.text: Loom-hours treated as asset capable of transfer; respondent sold surplus due to inability to use full quota from preparatory inefficiency.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Transfer is sale, not letting out; no interest retained, unlike plant rental.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Shri Lakshmi Silk Mills: there plant retained, temporarily let out; here loom-hours sold outright, cannot be let while retaining property.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sale of asset (not circulating capital) yields capital receipt.

court_reasoning.text: Disagrees with Allahabad HC in IT Misc. Case 177/1960: surplus disposed of completely, no exploitation while retaining ownership.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Receipt by sale of loom-hours is capital receipt, not income.

holdings.text: Receipts from sale of loom-hours are capital receipts and not taxable as income.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Excess Profits, Bombay City v. Shri Lakshmi Silk Mills Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Receipt from exploitation of commercial asset (plant let out temporarily while retaining ownership) is business income; unlike outright sale of loom-hours.

precedents_cited.case_name: Maheshwari Devi Jute Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P., Lucknow
precedents_cited.citation: I.T. Misc. Case No. 177 of 1960, decided on September 13, 1962
precedents_cited.relevance: Held sale of loom-hours as income from exploitation of commercial asset; Court disagrees as no ownership retained.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal; exemption for casual non-recurring receipts not capital gains and not from business; applied to hold receipts capital, not taxable.

outcome.summary: The appeals preferred by the Commissioner of Income-tax are dismissed. The High Court was right in holding that the receipts from sale of loom-hours were capital receipts and not taxable.
outcome.relief_granted: Receipts held not liable to tax

key_quotes.text: "Receipt by the exploitation of a commercial asset is the profit of the business, irrespective of the manner in which the asset is exploited by the owner of the business"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle from Lakshmi Silk Mills, applied but distinguished.

key_quotes.text: "Loom-hours cannot from their very nature be let out while retaining property in them, for there can be no grant of a temporary right to use loom-hours."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key distinction making transaction a sale, yielding capital receipt.

key_quotes.text: "Receipt by sale of loom-hours must therefore be regarded in this case as a capital receipt and not income."
key_quotes.speaker: court
